Award.AwardTitle: Strategic Needs of Water on the Yukon (SNOWY)
Award.AbstractNarration:
SNOWY is a collaborative project between Subarctic Indigenous communities in the Yukon River Basin (YRB) and scientists from Colorado State University (CSU), the US Geological Survey (USGS), the US Forest Service (USFS), and the grassroots, non-profit organization, the Yukon River Inter-Tribal Watershed Council (YRITWC) to combine qualitative and quantitative data on water quality and quantity of the Yukon River. Building upon the existing partnership and water-quality monitoring program between the USGS and the YRITWC, established in 2005 to measure the effects of climate change on the biogeochemistry of the Yukon River, SNOWY will provide a holistic view of how climate change is affecting Yukon River communities by exploring the social/cultural/economic/spiritual relationships of local people to the annual hydrologic cycle of the YRB. Utilizing community capacity that was developed as a key component of the water-quality monitoring project, SNOWY will collect snow and water data during the winter, complementing the existing summer data collection, and create a database that truly reflects the hydrology of the system. CSU and USGS scientists are working with community members through meetings, workshops, and interviews in order to a gain a more complete understanding of the social and environmental changes in the YRB in recent years.

A key component of the project is the "Healing Journey", a field trip taken by scientists and community members to travel a portion of the Yukon River by dog sled and/or snowmachine in the winter months. YRITWC has conducted a number of summertime Healing Journeys in order to bring together community and scientific understandings of the YRB and the changes taking place. Previous Healing Journeys have been conducted in traditional open water transports, such as canoes. The YRITWC has found that arriving via traditional transport creates an instant rapport with local people who are then willing and interested to learn more about the science that accompanies the trip. By employing this same technique in the winter season the SNOWY?s 300-mile Healing Journey will begin at Russian Mission, travel to the mouth of the Yukon and end at the community of Chevak, a coastal community on a tributary of the Yukon River. Although many of the research questions and hypotheses have been developed, the SNOWY team anticipates that others will arise through community dialogs that will be facilitated during the project.

Yukon River communities were involved in the conceptualization of this project and will be directly involved in the research through training, data gathering, analysis, and the sharing and exchange of knowledge, both scientific and indigenous that will take place throughout the course of this project. Scientists and communities will be working together in order to push the boundaries of current epistemological and ontological thinking while creating real solutions to climate change impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Strategic Needs of Water on the Yukon (SNOWY)

Indigenous arctic and subarctic communities currently are facing a myriad of social and environmental changes. Arctic temperatures in the late 20th century were the highest they have been in the past 400 years (Overpeck et al. 1997) and temperatures in Alaska have increased by a mean of 1.7oC between 1949 and 2012 (Bieniek et al. 2014) with winter and spring temperatures having the largest increases (Wendler et al. 2012). Increased temperature will likely change water chemistry, alter permafrost distribution (Jorgenson et al. 2006, Romanovsky et al. 2008, Frey and McClelland 2009), increase glacier melt, increase discharge, and alter inputs to the eastern Bering Sea (Walvoord and Streigl 2007, Walvoord et al. 2012). All of these changes have the potential to impact human existence and biophysical processes and roles in the Arctic. Our study focused on understanding the relationship of communities in subarctic Alaska with the environment including the documentation of observations of environmental change. Furthermore, we linked local observations of environmental change with physical science data through the collection of water samples and snow measurement.

This project took place in four villages in the Lower Yukon River Basin and Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta region: St. Mary’s, Pilot Station, Kotlik, and Chevak and two additional water and snow sampling locations: the Yukon River upstream of Kotlik and Kawanek Pass, a major distributary for the Yukon River into the Bering Sea. Seven researchers from the United States Geological Survey (USGS), Yukon River Inter-Tribal Watershed Council (YRITWC), United States Forest Service (USFS), and Colorado State University (CSU) traveled to the Lower Yukon River and Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta locations described above and conducted interviews, held participatory mapping workshops, collected under-ice water samples and made snow measurements with middle school and high school participation in February 2014.  A follow up visit took place in May with three researchers (USGS, YRITWC, CSU) returning to the community to share and verify preliminary results and community products.

Fifty-five interviews were conducted, three participatory mapping workshops were held, 6 under-ice water samples were collected, and snow measurements were completed at 6 locations over the course of this project. The results of the interviews show that residents of this region are observing and experiencing the impacts of climate change, particularly in the winter season. Maps created during the participatory mapping workshops showed areas of subsistence use during each season and highlight that the spatial extent of movement for each season varies. Under-ice water samples as well as snow measurements add to the USGS-YRITWC summer time water-quality database and increase our understanding of winter hydrology in this region.    

In conjunction with field work conduced in February 2014 presentations on this project as well as historic scientific research conducted in this region were given at each of the schools. Presentations and posters on this project have been given at the Alaska Forum on the Environment, the YRITWC biennial summit in Minto, AK July 2015 in which representatives from communities of the Yukon River Basin were in attendance.
